ETYMOLOGY: Middle English, from awe + -ful. Originally meant 'inspiring awe' or 'worthy of respect/fear'. The modern negative sense developed through semantic weakening and intensification.
SINCE: Late 13th century (original meaning); early 19th century (modern negative meaning)

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Extremely bad, unpleasant, or poor in quality; dreadful.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 极坏的；糟糕的；可怕的；很差的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The food at the new restaurant was absolutely awful.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那家新餐馆的食物真是糟透了。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used informally to mean extremely great; very large or many.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 极大的；大量的 (非正式，用作强调数量或程度)。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: I had an awful lot of work to finish before the deadline.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 在截止日期前我有大量的工作要完成。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Inspiring deep respect, fear, or wonder; full of awe.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 令人敬畏的；威严的 (古老或文学用法)。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: They bowed before the awful presence of the mountain deity.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他们在山神的威严面前鞠躬。

REGISTER: General usage, though sense 2 is informal and sense 3 is literary or dated.
